content.content:
CREATE TABLE superhero
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    superhero_name TEXT default NULL,
    full_name      TEXT default NULL,
    gender_id      INTEGER          default NULL,
    eye_colour_id  INTEGER          default NULL,
    hair_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    skin_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    race_id        INTEGER          default NULL,
    publisher_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    alignment_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    height_cm      INTEGER          default NULL,
    weight_kg      INTEGER          default NULL,
    foreign key (alignment_id) references alignment(id),
    foreign key (eye_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (gender_id) references gender(id),
    foreign key (hair_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (publisher_id) references publisher(id),
    foreign key (race_id) references race(id),
    foreign key (skin_colour_id) references colour(id)
);

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claude-code-claimdb/test_dbs/superhero.sqlite" "SELECT c.colour, COUNT(*) as cnt FROM superhero s JOIN colour c ON s.hair_colour_id = c.id GROUP BY c.colour ORDER BY cnt DESC LIMIT 10;"

content.text:
The data shows the count of superheroes by hair color. "Blond" ranks **3rd** with 105 superheroes, after "No Colour" (246) and "Black" (166).

However, the claim is about "audience popularity polls," which is not something stored in this database. The database only contains superhero attributes — there are no popularity poll columns or tables. The claim introduces an external concept ("audience popularity polls") that cannot be verified from the data.
